origination.corpname: Comparative Studies in Society and History

did.unittitle:
Comparative Studies in Society and History records
1956-1981
did.abstract: Comparative Studies in Society and History (CSSH ) is an international quarterly journal founded by Sylvia Thrupp in 1958. Its goal was to bring together specialists in all branches of the social sciences and humanities to create truly comparative scholarship, review articles and books, and to bring readers in touch with current findings and issues across disciplines. These records document the CSSH during Sylvia Thrupp's tenure as editor from 1956 to 1974. The bulk of the material consists of correspondence between journal contributors (scholars, editors, publishers) and the CSSH staff as well as administrative records covering 1956 to 1980.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: These records were donated by the Comparative Studies in Society and History ((Donor no. 10101) in August 2008.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Comparative Studies in Society and History records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: CSSH was founded by Sylvia Lettice Thrupp in October 1958. An early press release for CSSH stated that "the purpose of the journal is to serve as a clearing house for substantive work on problems common to any two or more of the disciplines dealing with man's life in society." Initially referred to as The Journal of Historical Comparisons, Thrupp founded the journal at the University of Chicago, where she served as a professor. From 1961 to 1977, Thrupp held the Alice Freeman Palmer Chair at the University of Michigan. Though she brought the journal with her to Michigan, CSSH remained an independently run organization. Its operations were initially funded by a grant from the Ford Foundation and through small donations from a handful of American universities.

In 1955, Thrupp sent out an informational circular to anthropologists, historians, art historians, sociologists, economists, and political scientists from around the world. Thrupp hoped to measure interest in the publication while soliciting advice and articles from her colleagues. Support for a journal was not universally embraced by her fellow academics. Historians in particular worried that the scholarship in their field was already too scattershot and that cross-disciplinary studies would produce articles by "sloppy thinkers." (See Box 1 Original circular Responces, James Ackerman) One responder warned that, "historians who stress the subject as a social science seldom write anything of importance, or produce anything with the artistic merit." (See Box 1 Original circular Responces, Carl Bindenbaugh) Others voiced excitement for the project but offered guarded enthusiasm that CSSH could produce three whole volumes a year with a consistently high level of scholarship.

CSSH's first issue appeared in October 1958 and was published by the Dutch publisher Mouton Publishers. Between grants, subscriptions, and exchanging advertising with other journals, CSSH flourished under Thrupp's leadership. In 1968, CSSH left Mouton and started a relationship with Cambridge University Press, the journal's current publisher.

Part of CSSH's mission was to support studies rooted in independent research. They did not accept articles that were published elsewhere even in different translations or versions. Along with scholarly articles, CSSH published short book reviews in the "Notes" section, and often published full academic discussions with arguments about articles and the author's reply.

The CSSHBook Series, edited by Raymond Grew, are collections of previously published articles compiled around one topic. These articles are revised and are supplemented by newly commissioned essays. Individual volumes are designed with specific audiences in mind, with potential for classroom use a primary consideration. In addition to the book series, Thrupp created indexes that codified articles by topic (rubrics) to draw attention away from geography, era, and discipline.

While Thrupp was the editor of CSSH, she worked closely with Daphne Grew and later Patricia Shoup as manuscript editors. Other important members of the editorial committee during this period include Raymond Grew, GE von Grunebaum, Everett C. Hughes, Edward A. Kracke, Jr., Max Rheinstein, Edward Shils, Sol Tax, Eric Wolf, and Aram Yengoyan. By 1975 they had 27 academic editors from around the world drawn from a dozen disciplines.

arrangement.p: Records of the journal Comparative Studies for Society and History consist of eleven linear feet of documents. The collection was stored in a filing cabinet and a number of boxes at the CSSH office. The original file order has been maintained. The CSSH collection is made up of seven series: Foundation Records; Advertising; Audits and Financial Records; Board and Editorial Meeting Reports and Minutes; Content Contributors Correspondence; Publisher; and Project Planning.

scopecontent.p: Records document the CSSH during Sylvia Thrupp's tenure as editor, and date from 1956 to 1974. The bulk of the material consists of correspondence between journal contributors (scholars, editors, publishers) and the CSSH staff as well as administrative records covering 1956 to 1980. Records include correspondence

scopecontent.p: The Foundation Records series (0.25 linear feet) contains both official organization records (incorporation and bylaws), and also historical records such as responses to a 1956 circular asking scholars from around the world and across disciplines for ideas and support for Sylvia Thrupp's proposed Journal of Historical Comparison. The "Historical Records" folder was compiled "for purposes of historical record of CSSH, of utility to editors." It contains a variety of materials from early letters of support to the requests for scholars to write articles for the journal to the 1968 contract between CSSH and Cambridge University Press.

The Advertising series (0.75 linear feet) contains correspondence between Thrupp or managing editor Daphne Grew and various advertising outlets. Early on, CSSH invested in commercial advertising to build awareness among scholars and libraries. They also engaged in exchanging journals, advertisements, and abstracts with other journal publishers as an economical way to grow their community and circulation. CSSH had special interest in a global market that included Russia, India, Australia and Latin America as well as the United States and Europe. This effort at global outreach stemmed directly from Thrupp's desire for a truly comparative and academically rigorous publication.

Exchange of Ad Notices without Exchange of Journals

scopecontent.p: The Audits & Financial Records series (0.75 linear feet) is made up of 4 subseries: Audit and Accounting, Ford Foundation Correspondence, Funding, and Savings and Loans Accounts. The audit reports summarize CSSH's yearly expenses including salaries and wages, travel expenses, telephone and telegraph bills, office supplies, printing and publication costs, postage and mimeograph services, and other expenses. By the late 1960s, CSSH hired Icerman, Johnson & Hoffman to produce audit reports. Also included in this series is correspondence from Max Rheinstein, Comparative law professor at the University of Chicago who gave general counsel on budgetary and non-profit tax issues.

The journal was initially funded through a grant from the Ford Foundation and donations from a small number of American Universities. This series largely contains requests and acknowledgements of donations with some invoices and ledgers. Also included are receipts from the University of Chicago where CSSH was first based. The Savings and Loans Accounts are made up of passbooks and general bank correspondence such as requests for interest amounts and requests to close the accounts. Also in this series are investment statements from Waitling-Lerchen.

did.unittitle: University of Chicago over Ford Foundation
Closing Out Savings and Loans Accounts, 1969
Board and Editorial Meeting Reports and Minutes

scopecontent.p: The Board and Editorial Meeting Reports and Minutes series (0.25 linear feet) contains agendas, notes, and minutes for Board of Directors' Meetings, Annual Meetings, and Editorial Meetings. The Editorial Meetings folders also contain board member searches and information on publishing business and journal content. The folder labels are not standardized so as to maintain their original labels folder names.

did.unittitle: Minutes and Reports -- Board Meetings Info on Publishers, 1980
Minutes and Reports -- To the Editorial Committee
Minutes and Reports -- Editorial Board Suggestions, 1978

scopecontent.p: The Content Contributor Correspondence series (6 linear feet) consists of seven subseries: Contributors, Critics, Editors, Miscellaneous, Rejected Contributors, Reviewers, and Withdraws. Most of the correspondence were stored in a filing cabinet and organized by year and type (contributor, editor etc). The original folder ordering has been preserved as well as their alphabetical ordering by last name. The majority of the correspondence are typed and the files contain copies of the outgoing letters as well as the original incoming letters. Correspondence are generally typewritten and are primarily in English, though occasional incoming letters are in French, German, and Spanish.

Though the Content Contributor Correspondence series comprises the bulk of the correspondence dealing with the journal's content, each series this collection contains correspondence related to its topic, such as copyright or publishers.

The Contributors subseries contains correspondence between CSSH scholarly contributors and the CSSH staff, primarily Sylvia Thrupp and the managing editor Daphne Grew. Letter contents include discussions about research, accepting articles for publication, and the drafting and editing of the articles, Also mixed into this subseries are letters from other kinds of contributors covered more specifically in the following subseries (e.g. editors, reviewers etc.). The Prospective Contributors files collect correspondence with scholars who voiced interested in having an article published in CSSH but never did. Their articles were not rejected, but rather further collaboration did not materialize. Occasionally, these correspondence are with scholars specializing in comparative studies whom CSSH targeted for contributions. These items are organized by year and in their original alphabetical order.

The Contributors subseries contains correspondence between CSSH scholarly contributors and the CSSH staff, primarily Sylvia Thrupp and the managing editor Daphne Grew. Letter contents include discussions about research, accepting articles for publication, and the drafting and editing of the articles, Also mixed into this subseries are letters from other kinds of contributors covered more specifically in the following subseries (e.g. editors, reviewers etc.). The Prospective Contributors files collect correspondence with scholars who voiced interested in having an article published in CSSH but never did. Their articles were not rejected, but rather further collaboration did not materialize. Occasionally, these correspondence are with scholars specializing in comparative studies whom CSSH targeted for contributions. These items are organized by year and in their original alphabetical order.

The Editors subseries primarily consists of correspondence between Sylvia Thrupp or Daphne Grew, and the volunteer editors for CSSH. Correspondence topics include outreach to potential board members and editors, members leaving the board, outreach to scholars for editing particular articles, critiques, and editing notes. Some entire exchanges are paper-clipped together and include the back-and-forth between contributors and editors for refining a paper. Manuscripts, however, are not included in these exchanges.

The Miscellaneous Correspondence subseries includes requests for announcements and book reviews from other journals and publishers, for complimentary copies of books to be reviewed in CSSH, and for bibliographies on comparative studies. There is no explicit order to the file but the bulk of the letters are from 1972.

The Rejected Contributors subseries collects the correspondence between Thrupp and the other managing editors with contributors whose articles did not get published. Typically, there were 3-5 letters per exchange including a request for publication and a rejection letter that offers a critique of the article and recommends other possible publishing options.

There are two rejection files that are limited to single contributors. Michael Bodeman was a contributor whom submitted an article for publication and then, after considerable collaboration with CSSH published his article in another journal. The article in question was pulled from CSSH publication. Hans Medick, a professor at the Max-Plank-Institut fur Geschichte, also has his own correspondence folder. He submitted an English translation of a conference paper on "Work Process" to CSSH . Because it had already been published it was not accepted.

The Reviewers subseries collects the correspondence between Thrupp and scholars that she solicited to contribute book reviews. The majority of this series' content is outgoing letters from Thrupp with few responses or replies.

Judging by the extant documentation, CSSH incurred very few article withdrawals during Thrupp's tenure. Only 2 cases are preserved here during the years 1971-1972. It is possible that others were not recorded, not saved, or were not separated from the other contributor files. Language from the existing correspondence gives the impression that this was a rare occurrence.

Judging by the extant documentation, CSSH incurred very few article withdrawals during Thrupp's tenure. Only 2 cases are preserved here during the years 1971-1972. It is possible that others were not recorded, not saved, or were not separated from the other contributor files. Language from the existing correspondence gives the impression that this was a rare occurrence.

The Publishers series (1.75 linear feet) documents the interaction between CSSH and their publishers including: correspondence, contracts, complementary subscription requests, invoices, and publicity plans. The series is organized into five subseries. Three publisher subseries: Mouton (1958-1968), Alden and Mowbray (1968-1969), and Cambridge University Press (1968-1973); Copyright; and Permission to Reproduce.

The three publisher subseries concentrate largely on business correspondence such as inquiries on subscription levels, confirming author contracts and deadlines, promotion planning and account balances. The folder "Correspondence on New Accounts" was put together by CSSH during their separation settlement with Mouton and includes documents from 1958 to 1972 when they switched publishers.
The Copyright subseries contains the copyright applications for all of the CSSH issues between 1959 and 1973. Also included are copyright guidelines and correspondence on copyright.

The Permission to Reproduce subseries collects requests from other publishers and scholars to reproduce entire articles or portions of articles in their publications or scholarship. Often CSSH made fee-based agreements for these requests.
The Project Planning series (1.1 linear feet) focuses on planning documents and correspondence surrounding the construction of journal issues, supplemental books, and the Innovation Conference.

The Bulletins subseries has the circulars sent out to potential contributors that discuss specific questions or comparative topics that CSSH hoped to address. The first Bulletin is a guide to contributors.

The supplemental books documented in this series include Immigrants and Associations, ed. L.A. Fallers, 1967, a collection of 6 essays on China, Singapore and Madagascar and Lebanon, West Africa, and Ibo in Calabar; Supplement 1: Intellectual Between Tradition and Modernity, by Edward Shils, 1961; Supplement 2: Millennial Dreams in Action, ed. Sylvia Thrupp, first published in 1962, and reprinted in 1970; Supplement 3: Social Mobility in the Caste System in India: An Interdisciplinary Symposium. ed. James Silverberg, 1968, revised papers from a symposium held at the annual meetings of the Association for Asian Studies, Chicago, 1961.

The Book/Supplement Planning files include correspondence between the authors and editors and contain book reviews of the volume. The Offprint Opinions folder consists of a discussion about the numbers of free copies given out to contributors.

Supplement 3, Social Mobility in the Caste System -- Reviews and Correspondence, 1961-1970

scopecontent.p: The Innovation Conference, May 4-6, 1967, was a conference organized by CSSH and sponsored by the Central Sesquicentennial Committee. This subseries documents the business planning and later publication of the conference papers. The "Dead File" Non-Participants folder is primarily correspondence with scholars who could not participate in the conference or whose papers were rejected.

The Issue Planning subseries consists of documents on tentative plans, issue contents, article page lengths, layout and space estimates, footnotes, and indexes. Notes Published are short blurbs published in the Notes section that identify important recent scholarly publications.

did.unittitle: Alden -- Length Estimating and Style Manual
Complete Space Estimates for Published Articles, 1974-1979

scopecontent.p: This Project Planning series also contains plans for books and projects that were never realized including a book on cartoons and extensive notes and letters between contributors, publishers, and the editorial board on the never completed Comparing Cities supplement. Thrupp's interest in a series on cities can be traced back to at least CSSH 4:1 (November 1961) in her review article on The Creativity of Cities .
